column4: nrossin--> when you do   ipcs  how many rows have their last column (status) blank?
nrossin--> under bytes how much do they take up?
nrossin--> btw, which ubuntu version do you have?
Stagger_Lee--> i hope you realized that using your ISP's dns would not allow you to resolve, 192.x ip addresses right?
not true
nrossin--> you can try to remove them with ipcrm,  I dont know the options off hand, man ipcs, man ipcrm
hatter--> does your ISP address resolve 192.x.x.x addresses?
dns has one purpose, map human readable names to ip addresses
nrossin--> go ahead and reboot
hatter--> you did not answer me, can your ISP dns server resolve a 192.x.x.x address?
you are speaking of ip addresses,  dns resolves names to ip addresses
hatter--> and likewise in reverse noh?  you have not answered my question yet
no an internet dns does not resolve a name to an internet non-routable address
that is not the point
correct
the point is, he is trying to get to his router via an ip address
to which, dns has no part
hatter and if he is using the ISP dns server to resolve an ip address thats 192.x.x.x it would not work
no it doesnt, but no router asks for a domain name.
they need an ip address on the same subnet
which doesnt need any dns
correct, if in same subnet
